channel.title: Comments on: SQL Server DBA Tip 3 – Server Configuration â€“ Model Database
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: David Forck (thirster42)
item.dc:creator: David Forck (thirster42)
item.description: antoher great addition to model are schemas that you reuse across databases. for example all of my reporting services sp's go into an rs schema, so having the rs schema in the model database saves me time.
item.content:encoded: antoher great addition to model are schemas that you reuse across databases. for example all of my reporting services sp’s go into an rs schema, so having the rs schema in the model database saves me time.

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.description: A key point to remember is the fact that this is a template (good description). Changes or additions that you make to the model database only apply to _new_ databases that you create after the change, they aren't retroactive (which would be a little scary in some cases).
item.content:encoded: A key point to remember is the fact that this is a template (good description). Changes or additions that you make to the model database only apply to _new_ databases that you create after the change, they aren’t retroactive (which would be a little scary in some cases).

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: Good post. Model can also be used if you want to make sure that every new database has a certain table or a certain proc
item.content:encoded: Good post. Model can also be used if you want to make sure that every new database has a certain table or a certain proc
